reviewText: I saw this film recently at the Philadelphia Qfest.  What a stinkerroo!!  The film appeared to be shot using video, which has none of the lighting nuances or shadows associated with film.  The sets and settings were so poorly constructed, that I was counting the seams and nailholes on the backdrop.  It appears that shooting in video highlights every defect, especially since the lighting was glaring.  However, as this will be viewed mostly on small screen, perhaps those defects won't be so evident.As to the cast, I will be kind and say that these guys didn't look like deer in the headlights all of the time.  The lead actor's protrayal was weak, especially since he was taking a moral high ground.  The supporting players appeared as if they came off the street to do the director a favor.  At best, the lead's best male friend appeared to be doing a takeoff of Tony Danza.The story line is a relevant one, to have an open/closed relationship and surely one that deserves a better treatment than what it got here.  Save your money or at best, buy used and then try and resell.  It is not worthy of a place in your permanent collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You could use one word to describe just about every aspect of this film: "LOW". I couldn't get Ronnie Kerr's constant grinning off my mind while watching this flick. So when he cried in the movie, I still think he's grinning. I think if the entire screenplay had been shortened to a 20-25 minute, quasi "Sex in the City" episode, it might have been more effective.

reviewText: It is obviously a cheaply made movie, But the actors are hot.  The Main guy is a little too whinny for me, and the love interest is a little too cocky.  I must say that there are alot of funny moments that make you out and out laugh, but the ending, in my opinion is quite a let down.I don't want to ruin it, but let me say, no one should have to settle.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ben is a 35 year old gay man, who is unlucky in finding someone to love, despite his friends' best efforts to help him through the maze of video and online services as well as fixing him up on blind dates.  When he notices a runner going past his house at a certain time each day, he makes it a point to be out there, and eventually meets Grey.  They begin to date, and are very compatible on many levels, except one:  Ben wants a committed, monogamous relationship, and Grey doesn't see that as a possibility for him.Written (based on his own experiences) and produced by Ronnie Kerr (who some may remember as the lead in "Regarding Billy"), who also stars as Ben.  The concept was good, and there are some realistic, emotional scenes that are done very well. However, while I realize the movie was shot in one week, directly on video with a tiny budget, the overall quality of the production did detract from what could have been much better with a bit more effort and care.  I also thought the ending was a significant cop-out that evaded the point of the story. However, I do give them credit for using realistic-looking 30-something actors (who did a good job, with the material they had to work with), rather than the usual model-quality, buff "actors" seen in many gay films. Overall, I don't see this as more than three stars out of five.
summary: Good concept, marginal execution, big cop-out.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For an obviously very low budget film I thought it was Ok.  Many of the scenes were quite good and the relationship between the two leads was quite believable.  It tackles a sensitive subject quite well - but as other reviewers have mentioned I too must agree that the ending was quite disappointing.  I think everyone deserves to have their standards and the film seems to suggest that "give in".  Love is NEVER enough to maintain a relationship.  Two people MUST have common ideas, values and goals in order for it to last.  The film says that Love is what is left after you stop judging.  This is TRUE, but it does not mean that you should let go of your personal standards in a relationship, as it seems to suggest.

reviewText: It's a feel-good movie that tackles the tough theme of monogamy / lack thereof in the gay world in a sensitive and loving way. Very, very good lead actor and director. Looks / feels like a low-budget film that should merit the director more gigs.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film explores the difficulties of finding a love-connection outside the bar scene and online-dating.  Apparently snagging a partner off the sidewalk while watering your lawn provides just as many pitfalls.  The question of the validity of monogamy within a gay relationship evolves as the acid test of its viability.  According to this script, insistence on monogamy is a refusal to love people as they are with all their faults, including betrayal.  This 180-degree turn lacks any justification within the film and left this viewer disappointed.

reviewText: I've watched loads of gay rom movies, a few of them with these same actors even, but this one stands out because of the great conversations which the two leads have. Realistic and emotionally charged, fleshing out the characters well.

reviewText: From reading the reviews, I expected the worst, but was pleasantly surprised. While this isn't a top notch gay romantic comedy like "All Over the Guy", it is entertaining. I thought the production value was fairly good for a low budget film. I enjoyed the second half more than the first half, but I have to agree with others on the ending.  The ending was quite unsatisfying, in that it sends the wrong message that it's okay just to settle for someone in a situation that you really don't want.
summary: Not as bad as I expected.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a film about love and unrealistic expectations.  When you watch this scenario being played out, remember the virtual and complete dicotomny of these two(2)men.  Both are very much in love with each other, but one requires continual outside sexual escapades, while the other is set in his ways in monogynist beliefs.  Neither one is willing to change until a break-up forces each to realize that a loving relationship will require some complete modification of each of their rock bound beliefs.  This is how love, tru-love changes both of them and keeps them together.  What a film!  What a morale to human life and love!  SOMETIMES LOVE, TRU-LOVE WILL FIND A WAY, GIVEN HALF A CHANCE!!  NJMJr.

reviewText: This film is not  very long and  is moves at a  snail's pace in the  early scenes. It has all been done before  and  is cliched in parts.Like most gay films ,it has been written by someone with little experience in writing - there is almost no feeling in the film. Nothing original at all. Does anyone care  about the characters? I think not.There are plenty of far better  gay films  around ( especially in Hong Kong and Europe).

reviewText: I have seen this one soon after I saw "Singing forest" and I must admit that it is worth the second star. I didn't find it difficult to watch it from the beginning to the very last minute.The movie is very very amateurish, but as I mentioned above, has its moments.The whole idea could be even more entertaining if only the filmmakers had some more cash to shoot it properly.The acting is not good, but at least people, who star in it,  don't try too much to prove that they are real actors:) They read their lines and that's it.There is a lot of talk in this movie about gays, dated by the main character, who appeared to be jerks, morons etc.Unfortunately, it is our hero who is the biggest jerk, giving up his dreams and beliefs to be with notorious cheater. So, the ending is quite disappointing.

reviewText: Remarkably unfunny comedy that turns into a remarkably unmoving drama about a gay man (Ronnie Kerr) looking for Mr. Right and always finding Mr. Wrong.  Bad writing (Kerr again), bad acting, obnoxious characters.  Nothing about this one is good.  I suppose we're supposed to feel for this guy and the pain he puts himself through, but who cares?  He's a loser from beginning to end (especially the end), and so is this movie.  Don't waste your time.
